titleStmt.title: A multi-objective pharmaceutical supply chain network based on a robust fuzzy model: A comparison of meta-heuristics

analytic.title: A multi-objective pharmaceutical supply chain network based on a robust fuzzy model: A comparison of meta-heuristics

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The pharmaceutical industry is defined as a system of processes, operations, and organizations involved in the discovery, development, and production of drugs. The pharmaceutical supply chain network (PSCN) is a way through which pharmaceutical products with suitable quality are distributed at a suitable time and place to reach final customers [1]. Accordingly, it is considered a global industry with a high impact on human life. Thus, disturbances in production or distribution can endanger the lives of humans by creating problems of access to drug items. The use of optimization tools in the PSCN domain has therefore remained a permanent interest for researchers and scientists [1,2]. The growth of the drug market in the world over the past few years and the expansion of the range and variety of these products in the global market, together with the importance of its close association with human health, has led to an increase in the need to optimize the distribution methods of these products in order to reach consumers as easily as possible [2].

Undoubtedly, one of the most important criteria for the advancement of the community is its state of health, which is directly linked to the timely and sufficient supply of crucial drugs [3]. The prediction of the need for drugs and the ordering of drugs to the necessary extent and at the time required is a basic principle of health care [2,3]. The process of supplying and distributing drugs is not only affected by the functioning of an institution or organization, but to the smooth operation of a chain of organizations (the PSCN) that contribute to the efficiency of this process.

One of the most important segments of the drug distribution system is the distribution to pharmacies located in health centers (hospitals), since it is the pharmacy's responsibility to provide the necessary drugs for all the treatments in the health center. Henceforth, supply chain reliability is of great importance, related to the probability that the flow of products from supply points to demand points is less than the actual demand [4]. Furthermore, the problem that can impose many costs on the supply chain is the inadequacy of the various layers of the supply chain. The ability to perform the required tasks is defined under terms expressed as reliability. Thus, the importance and quality of reliability in the supply chain network design are highlighted [5].

In this regard, distribution performance indicates the effect of the displacement and the sphere of influence of manufactured products. Advancements in technical matters and management principles lead to improvements in load-displacement, speed, quality of service, operating costs, capacity utilization, and energy consumption. Multi-modal transportation is the most important branch in the economic system of the PSCN, given that most of the costs in the PSCN are related to the transportation system. In the PSCN, multi-modal transportation is one of the limiting factors in determining markets. Consequently, transportation plays a significant role in the product's benefits. In the PSCN, overall costs change by choosing different transportation modes; but in general, road transport reduces the total cost of the network, since there are no warehousing and storage costs in this type of transport and all costs are calculated along the exact route.

The multi-modal transportation system is not included in the PSCN problem in any papers and studies. Also, the reliability of the transportation system is important for the transportation of pharmaceutical products. Therefore, pharmaceutical items are of great importance for the successful performance of any health care system (such as pharmacies and hospitals) and any risk can instantly affect the entire PSCN. This problem can not only waste resources but also endanger the lives of patients due to lack of access to pharmaceutical products, which is considered for the first time in this network. In the examined problems, for example, in references [6], [14], [17], [22] and [23], the problems of allocation-distribution, location-allocation-distribution, production-routing-inventory, productionrouting, and routing are considered simultaneously, but the problem of production-distributionpurchasing-ordering-inventory holding-allocation-routing in this paper is considered respectively. In this paper, we introduce a multi-period, multi-product and multi-level PSCN problem formulation to minimize both the total cost and the delivery time of pharmaceutical products and to maximize the reliability of the transportation systems and routings in the network. Moreover, a three-objective MINLP model with multi-modal transportation is extended.

Examination of uncertainty-related papers, for instance, in references [14], [16], [20] and [21] are considered a robust approach, a possibilistic-stochastic method, a probability strategy, and a fuzzy technique, but a new fuzzy-robust programming technique for the PSCN is considered for the first time in this work. Then, the model is extended employing robust fuzzy programming to assess the impacts of uncertainty in certain parameter values.

The methodology solutions of mathematical models in the investigated papers are considered exact methods and meta-heuristic algorithms. According to the NP-hard and the complexity of the presented model, exact methods are considered in small-sized problems. Then, it is practically impossible to solve them at a specified time and also their use along with many constraints in practice is not appropriate. Papers related to solving methods, the use of metaheuristic algorithms are considered. For example, in papers [10], [57], [16], [20], [23] and [23] have used meta-heuristic algorithms to solve the model. Further, to solve the proposed model in the large-sized problems several J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Journal Pre-proof multi-objective metaheuristic algorithms including multi-objective social engineering optimization (MOSEO), multi-objective simulated annealing (MOSA), multi-objective keshtel algorithm (MOKA), multi-objective particle swarm optimization (MOPSO), and multi-objective firefly algorithm (MOFFA) algorithms are utilized and the outcomes are compared with each other. To summarize, the current paper demonstrates some concerns that cover the literature gaps and can be categorized as follows:

 Integrating production, distribution, purchasing, inventory holding, ordering, allocation, and routing decisions in the PSCN problem for the first time according to the papers analyzed in the literature review,  Considering three objective functions focusing on total cost, time as the significant objective because of the significance to deliver some pharmaceutical amount of products within the shortest timeframe, and reliability of transportation systems and routes in the PSCN,  Considering uncertainty for the parameters related to order, transportation, purchase, and delivery costs and capacity of the warehouse, the distribution centers, and the vehicles,  Developing a novel robust fuzzy approach to manage uncertainty in PSCN parameters,  Formulating a linearization of the non-linear PSCN model,  Proposing multi-objective metaheuristic algorithms to reach fast high-quality solutions,  Providing several sensitivity analyses on the main parameters. The rest of the present paper is organized as follows: section 2 discusses the literature review related to the PSCN, uncertainty, and metaheuristic algorithms; section 3 describes the problem as well as the mathematical formulation and assumptions of the developed model and fuzzy robust programming; section 4 introduces the proposed metaheuristic algorithms; section 5 provides quantitative analyses to evaluate the performance of the algorithms for a set of test problems with various complexities and sizes; section 6 reviews the main findings and managerial implications of the results; finally, the conclusions and suggestions for future studies are expressed in section 7.

div.head: Literature review
div.p: Over the recent years, along with the increasing significance in the industrial and academic sectors for the pharmaceutical supply chain, several general review papers have been published (see for instance [58]- [61]). These review papers contain references to the available literature in the area, determine the observed research gaps, and propose future work paradigms and fields. According to these reviews, our paper is related to two flows of PSCN research: firstly, papers devoted to metaheuristic algorithms; secondly, papers related to the management of uncertainty.

There exist multiple recent examples of the application of metaheuristics to solve PSCN problems. Sousa et al. provided a new global supply chain network optimization for pharmaceuticals. Also, an allocation-distribution problem in the multi-period and multi-echelon PSCN to maximize profit are addressed. Then, a mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model is formulated and several heuristic methods is suggested [6]. Susarla and Karimi developed integrated planning in multi-site, multi-period, and multi-echelon supply chain network for multi-national pharmaceutical companies. They formulated an MILP model to minimize the total cost in the production-distribution problem [7]. Hansen and Grunow suggested planning operations before market launch for balancing time-to-market and risks in the PSCN. They formulated a MILP model for the corresponding allocation and distribution problem [8]. Chung and Kwon designed an integrated PSCN structure considering the impact of item perishability within a framework that involves manufacturers, distribution centers, wholesalers, and demand markets [56]. Stuart and Ursavas analyzed a satellite network with direct delivery in the pharmaceutical industry. They proposed a technique that iterates between an upper bound and a lower bound according to the blended Lagrangian relaxation branch-and-cut approach [9]. Weraikat et al. improved sustainability in a bi-level PSCN with a Vendor-Managed Inventory system using a real case study [10]. Roshan et al. presented a new model for the PSCN in crisis periods and considered perishability and J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Journal Pre-proof substitutability of drugs in their mathematical model. They used two numerical methods to handle the multi-objective model [11]. Halim et al. illustrated a decision support structure and system for the design of a sustainable PSCN. They introduced a new decision support system, PharmaSC, extended by integrating two computer tools, an Excel-based AHP and LLamasoft's supply chain Guru [12]. Kumar and Jha proposed a new application of principles of supply chain management to the pharmaceutical good transportation practices [13].

With respect to uncertainty issues, Izadi and Kimiagari designed a location and allocation problem in pharmaceutical industry under demand uncertainty. A set of possible scenarios for customer demands was generated with a Monte Carlo approach to assess the effect of the uncertain parameters. They used a genetic algorithm to solve the problem, introducing a case study in pharmaceutical industry to validate the model and solution methodology [57]. Mousazadeh et al. developed a robust possibilistic programming method for PSCN design. They also formulated a bi-objective MILP for the PSCN design problem and a location-allocation-distribution problem in the PSCN [14]. Haji Abbas and Hosseininezhad proposed a discrete capacitated covering location-allocation model for the PSCN under a robust method [15]. Zandieh et al. presented a new resilient-sustainable model for the PSCN, introducing a new measure for resiliency and sustainability. They proposed a possibilistic-stochastic programming model to cope with uncertainty, and developed a new hybrid meta-heuristic algorithm to solve the problem [16]. Ghasemi Bijaghini and SeyedHosseini suggested a novel bi-level production, routing, and inventory model for a PSCN under uncertainty. They used a robust technique to cope with uncertainty parameters and applied the Benders decomposition algorithm to solve the model [17]. Zahiri et al. designed a new PSCN under a robust possibilistic method considering perishability and substitutability of products [18]. Sabouhi et al. utilized an integrated hybrid method according to the data envelopment analysis (DEA) and mathematical programming approach. They developed a twostage possibilistic-stochastic programming model for integrated supply chain design and supplier selection and applied it to a case study of pharmaceutical supply chain [19]. Savadkoohi et al. designed a multi-period three-level PSCN along with a new distribution-location-inventory model considering the perishable nature of pharmaceutical products. They introduced a possibilistic programming technique to deal with uncertainty, and examined its applicability with a real case study [20]. Taleizadeh et al. introduced a robust optimization approach for coordinating pharmaceutical reverse supply chains under return strategies in order to maximize profits for the members of the reverse supply chain [54]. Singh and Goh designed a multi-objective mixed integer programming in a PSCN, and suggested the use of intuitionistic fuzzy numbers for the uncertainty and hesitation arising from estimations [21]. Aghababaei et al. presented a two-stage fuzzy optimization model for the scarce drug rationing problem. Then, a rolling horizon mechanism and an iterative procedure for supplying and rationing the scarce drugs are used. Additionally, a robust possibilistic programming approach to cope with uncertainty parameters is applied [55]. Fanco and Alfonso-Lizarazo formulated two mixed integer programming (MIP) models in the PSCN under uncertainty. They used a simulation-optimization method according to the stochastic technique for tactical and operative decisions in the PSCN [22]. Nasrollahi and Razmi considered a new mathematical model for an integrated, four-layer, and multi-period PSCN with maximum expected coverage under uncertainty. They applied a multi-objective non-dominated ranked genetic algorithm, multi-objective particle swarm optimization, and non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm to solve the model [23].
To provide a structured classification of the above references with the help of terminology listed in Table 1, Table 2.1, and 2.2 summarize the most relevant papers in these fields.

div.head: Problem definition and mathematical formulation
div.p: This paper considers a multi-period multi-product PSCN including several internal and foreign manufacturing centers, distribution centers (DCs), warehouses as well as pharmacies and hospital pharmacies as customers. Foreign manufacturing centers are considered due to the possible shortage of pharmaceutical products in the internal manufacturing centers. Pharmaceutical products from internal and foreign manufacturing centers are sent to the warehouses and DCs, from warehouses to DCs and customers and from DCs to customers via the multi-modal transportation system. This distribution is based on demands and orders of pharmaceutical products and routes specified between levels. Each vehicle can complete one route per period, and each customer can receive more than one delivery (vehicle) of pharmaceutical products at any period. Deliveries from the internal and foreign manufacturing centers to the warehouses and DCs, from warehouses to DCs and customers (i.e., pharmacies and pharmacies in hospital) and from DCs to customers are completed on specified routes and at different periods. Re-orders are possible in the supplying of customer demands (i.e., pharmacies and hospital pharmacies) from warehouses and DCs and to supply warehouse demands and DCs demands from internal and foreign manufacturing centers, but customers are prioritized depending on the costs faced by the re-order process. Each customer's demand to distribution centers and warehouses, each distribution center's demand and each warehouse's demand to manufacturing centers are allocated during the planning horizon. At each time period, only vehicles allocated to distribution centers, warehouses, and internal and foreign manufacturing centers at that time can deliver pharmaceutical products to those customers, distribution centers and warehouses. There are no routes between internal and foreign manufacturing centers. The transportation cost of pharmaceutical products is variable and multi-modal transportation systems are considered. Pharmaceutical products may be transported by plane when there are airports at the corresponding PSCN nodes, or by road elsewhere. As a general assumption, the delivery of pharmaceutical products from foreign manufacturing centers will only be possible by plane. On the other hand, to save on delivery costs, batch deliveries are considered. Travel times from internal and foreign manufacturing centers to warehouses and DCs, from DCs and warehouses to customers (i.e., pharmacies and pharmacies in hospital) and between customers on the different specified routes are considered. In the DCs, the cost of packaging and preparation of orders is considered. Capacity limitations are also considered for internal and foreign manufacturing centers, warehouses, and DCs. The formulation also takes into account the reliability rate of the multi-modal transportation system and the specified routes. The structure of the presented PSCN containing internal and foreign manufacturing centers, warehouses, DCs, and customers is indicated in Figure 1.

div.head: Proposed mathematical model
div.p: This section describes the formulation of the mathematical model for the PSCN, including the three proposed objective functions and the full set of constraints.

div.head: Objective function 1
div.p: The first objective function seeks to minimize the total cost consisting of inventory holding, ordering, penalty, tariff, production, transportation, re-ordering, distribution, warehouse, fixed, purchasing, and delivery costs: Each one of these cost concepts is calculated as follows:

div.p: In (A), inventory costs are taken into account at the levels of the internal manufacturing center, foreign manufacturing center, warehouse and DC for pharmaceutical products. In (B), the costs are based on orders and demands for pharmaceutical products from DCs and warehouses to internal manufacturing centers and foreign manufacturing centers, from customers to DCs and warehouses, and from DCs to warehouses must be paid. In (C), penalty costs for delayed deliveries and deterioration of pharmaceutical products are computed. In (D), a tariff cost is considered for sending pharmaceutical products between nodes in the network using the air transport system, including deliveries to and from the airport. In (E), the production cost for pharmaceutical products in internal manufacturing centers and foreign manufacturing centers is considered. In (F), the variable cost of sending pharmaceutical products between different nodes in the network is considered at different period times and for different transport systems (air and land). In (G), we consider the cost of re-ordering pharmaceutical products from internal manufacturing centers and foreign manufacturing centers at the end of each period. In (H), the preparing and packaging cost of pharmaceutical products in DCs is considered. In (I), the inventory holding cost of pharmaceutical products in the warehouse is considered. In (J), there is a fixed cost for the opening of internal manufacturing centers, foreign manufacturing centers, and warehouses. In (K), the purchase costs of pharmaceutical products by DCs and warehouses from internal manufacturing centers and foreign manufacturing centers, by customers from DCs and warehouses, and by DCs of warehouses are computed. Finally, (L) corresponds to the fixed cost of delivery of pharmaceutical products, taking into account the delivery time between the nodes of the network.

div.p: The second objective function considered tries to minimize the delivery time of pharmaceutical products from internal and foreign manufacturing centers to warehouses and DCs, from warehouses to DCs, and from DCs to customers, as follows:

div.p: The third objective function seeks to maximize the reliability of the transportation system of pharmaceutical products, the routes between the network, and the distance from internal and foreign manufacturing centers to warehouses and DCs, from warehouses to DCs and customers, and from DCs to customers, as follows.

div.p: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Constraints (1)-( 4) indicate the capacity of the warehouse, DC, and the transportation systems in each period, respectively. Constraints ( 5)-( 13) indicate an allocated route between each warehouse and DC, each internal and warehouse, each foreign manufacturing center and warehouse, each internal manufacturing center and DC, each foreign manufacturing center and DC, each warehouse and customer, and each DC and customer. Constraints ( 14)-( 18) ensure that a warehouse is allocated for each DC, a DC for each customer (pharmacy and pharmacy in hospital), and a warehouse for each customer (pharmacy and pharmacy in hospital). Constraints ( 19)-( 25) specify the amount of pharmaceutical products delivered to each warehouse and the DC from the internal manufacturing center and the foreign manufacturing centers, to each DC from the warehouses, and to each customer from the DCs and the warehouses. Constraints ( 26)- (30) express flow balance at the warehouses and DCs, respectively. Constraints (31)- (34) represent inventory balance at the warehouses and DCs, respectively. Constraints (35) and (36) show the initial inventory at the warehouses and DCs. Constraints (37)- (40) impose the maximum number of used pharmaceutical products in internal and foreign manufacturing centers, warehouses, and DCs. Constraints ( 41)-( 48) ensure the routes of each vehicle in a succession, respectively. Constraints ( 49) and ( 50) guarantee that if a vehicle travels between two customers, at least a DC and a warehouse must be allocated to the route. Constraints ( 51)-(66) show the delivery time of pharmaceutical products from internal and foreign manufacturing centers to warehouses and DCs, from warehouses to DCs and customers, and from DCs to customers. Finally, constraints (67) and (68) define the eligible domains of decision variables.

div.head: Linearization of the objective function

div.head: Uncertainty modeling
div.p: Due to its relevance in practical applications, the consideration of uncertainty in the parameters of the PSCN is one of the key elements in our research. The sections below describe how we have addressed these issues.

div.head: Trapezoidal fuzzy programming technique
div.p: This section presents several fuzzy models, including chance constraint fuzzy programming, to tackle uncertainty in the parameters of the constraints and objective functions described above. This approach is based on the existence of ambiguity and vagueness in the objective function and constraints. The consideration of uncertainty in mathematical models uses different fuzzy number patterns like the triangular and the trapezoidal formulations [34]. The trapezoidal approach can be used to display the basic fuzzy programming model and the exigency measure to control the degree of constraint satisfaction. The basic mathematical model is as follows:

Suppose vector  (transportation and purchase costs) and  , (capacity of the warehouses, the distribution centers, and the vehicles) are the uncertain parameters of the model. div.head: Solution approach
div.p: As discussed in section 2, metaheuristic algorithms are the best option to obtain a near-optimal solution to the NP-hard PSCN problem. In the present paper, we propose several algorithms including MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA algorithms for solving the designed PSCN. Since our formulation consists of a three-objective optimization model, we first outline the multi-objective optimization framework. Afterward, the solution representation of the presented model is investigated by the metaheuristic algorithms.

div.head: Multi-objective optimization
div.p: Based on the three objective functions formulated, the presented PSCN corresponds to a type of multi-objective optimization problem. Hence, the optimum solution is a Pareto optimum frontier [35]. The best Pareto frontier is composed by the non-dominated solutions in comparison with other solutions generated by the metaheuristic procedures [36]. In this regard, the second front is made by all the other solutions that are only dominated by the solutions in the first one [35,36]. The assessment of our multi-objective algorithms will be carried out according to the multi-objective evaluation metrics linked to the quality of the first front of Pareto-based solutions [37].

div.head: Solution representation
div.p: An outline is generally required to decode and encode the solutions to the problem to enable the calculation of objective functions and search space in order to implement the algorithms to solve the optimization models [38,39]. The present paper uses a two-stage heuristic process called Random-Key [40]. This procedure aims to change the continuous search space of the algorithm to a feasible discreet one by utilizing several heuristic procedures [41].

The allocation, inventory, ordering, distribution, transportation, and routing decisions correspond to the significant decision variables of the model. The allocation variables containing the assignment of the warehouses to the DCs ( ) by different routes are illustrated in Figures 3 and4. From Figure 3, the twelve warehouses are assigned to four DCs by rounding the numbers. For instance, the warehouses containing 𝑤 2 , 𝑤 5 , 𝑤 9 , and 𝑤 11 are allocated to DC 𝑑 1 . From Figure 4, the nine internal and foreign manufacturing centers are assigned to three DCs again by rounding the numbers. For instance, the internal and foreign manufacturing centers containing 𝑚 3 , 𝑚′ To represent the distribution, production, and ordering of the manufacturing centers in each time period, the used the number of pharmaceutical products for each manufacturing center in each warehouse, DC, and customer should be investigated first. This is achieved by means of an array with the length of 𝜌 for the number of pharmaceutical products. Figure 5 shows an example with ten manufacturing centers. The numbers to determine the production, distribution, and ordering of the pharmaceutical products are sorted in ascending order. Then, according to the maximum desired number of distribution centers, manufacturing centers and warehouses, and according to the capacities of warehouses, DCs, and manufacturing centers, the different pharmaceutical products are allocated to them. In addition, to design the delivery routes for each time period, the utilized vehicles allocated to each manufacturing center, warehouse, DC, and customer should be chosen first. The method uses an array of the same length as 𝑉. A uniform distribution of 𝑈(0, 𝑣&𝑣 𝐴 ) is performed to create the initial values for 𝑅𝑣 and 𝑅𝑣 𝐴 , where 𝑣&𝑣 𝐴 are the vehicle types. Then, by rounding the created numbers, the type of vehicles per manufacturing center is specified. This method is illustrated in Figure 6, where manufacturing centers, 𝑉 1 , 𝑉 2 , 𝑉 4 , and 𝑉 6 are allocated to the first type of vehicle, and 𝑉 3 and 𝑉 5 to the second one.

div.head: Multi-objective social engineering optimization algorithm
div.p: The social engineering optimization (SEO) is an intelligent algorithm like many of the most recent metaheuristic procedures, and yet very simple, which only includes four steps and three parameters for calibration. The SEO algorithm was introduced by [42], inspired by the rules of social engineering as an emerging phenomenon in today's real world. The algorithm starts with two random solutions called the attacker and the defender. Also, search phases are based on the rules of social engineering in which the attacker uses certain techniques to achieve his desired goals. In this section, we first introduce the concepts of social engineering and then describe the method inspired by this phenomenon with the description and steps related to it.

In the proposed method, each solution expressing each individual and his characteristics, including her/his abilities in mathematics, sports, business, etc., corresponds to the variables of the problem. As mentioned earlier, this algorithm starts with two random solutions, with the better solution called the attacker and the other the defender. Therefore, in order to simulate the learner's training and retraining from the attacker to the defender, a series of random tests are defined for each attribute in which the attacker tests an attribute of the defender, the amount of learning is calculated and the new defender has the highest re-training rate if there is a replacement for the current defender. Further, attacks from the defender are carried out according to the techniques that are available to him. During these actions, the defender is transferred to the attacker's points in order to respond to the attacks and the defender is assessed and this process is repeated until the end of the strike, and if the defender is more valuable than the attacker, they are replaced by each other and a new defender is generated to restart the J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Journal Pre-proof procedure. In this algorithm, like other metaheuristic algorithms, different phases of the search are considered. Also, training and retraining of the defender and the attacker from each other forms a local search in the algorithm. Additionally, the attacker's attacks on the defender and the response to that focus phase are formed, and eventually, the choice of the new defender will correspond to the phase of diversity for this algorithm. For more information on the MOSEO algorithm, the reader can refer to [42]. Figure 7 shows the pseudo-code of the MOSEO algorithm.

div.head: Multi-objective simulated annealing algorithm
div.p: The simulated annealing (SA) algorithm for optimization problems was introduced first by [43]. Contrary to gradient-based methods and other exact search methods, whose main drawback is the local optimum traps, the main advantage of the SA algorithm is in its ability to avoid getting trapped in local optimal solutions. The SA algorithm is a search method based on a Markov chain, which converges the transfer probability function in appropriate conditions. This approach not only accepts changes that improve the target function, but it also accepts even some of the changes that do not improve, with a specific probability, in order to not to fall into local traps. The probability of accepting such solutions is dependent on the temperature parameter. For example, in minimization problems, not only any move or change that reduces the value of the objective function will be accepted, but changes that increase the value of the objective function have a certain probability of being accepted. For more information about the MOSA algorithm, the reader can refer to [44]. The pseudo-code of the MOSA algorithm is indicated in Figure 8.

div.head: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f
div.p: Journal Pre-proof inspired by the behavior of natural species to optimize nonlinear functions, being one of the most successful and at the same time low-cost algorithms. In this algorithm, each of one member of the group of fireflies moves to a point where his/her best personal experience has taken place. This algorithm is inspired by studies and observations on fireflies. These studies have shown that fireflies are social insects that live in colonies. One of the most important and interesting behaviors about fireflies is their ability to find food and especially how to find the shortest route between food and nest. This kind of behavior of fireflies is supported by a kind of mass intelligence that has recently been considered by scientists. At this point, it is important to clarify the difference between mass intelligence (colony) and social intelligence. In social intelligence, elements have a degree of intelligence. In mass intelligence, elements have random behavior, and there is no direct relationship between them, and they only interact with each other indirectly and using signs. For more information about the MOFFA algorithm, the reader can refer to [50]. Figure 11 shows the pseudo-code of the MOFFA algorithm, and the flowchart of the presented algorithms is shown in

div.head: Experimentation and computational results
div.p: This section provides in the first place the description of the test problems used to validate the solution procedures. Then the results obtained using the different solution techniques are also shown, including exact solution techniques for small-scale problems and metaheuristic algorithm for the larger ones.

div.head: Numerical examples and related model
div.p: This section describes the generation of a set of numerical instances for validating the developed fuzzy robust programming (FRP) model and also for evaluating the meta-heuristic algorithms used to solve it. Since there are no benchmarks existing in the literature for this particular PSCN problem, the definition of a specific approach was required to design the experiment problems. We generated 10 samples in large and small sizes. The sizes of the sample problems and the parameters used in each case are presented in Tables 3 and4, respectively. Then, the trapezoidal fuzzy numbers of the uncertain parameters were randomly generated based on a uniform distribution, which is shown in Table 5.

div.p: The value of uncertain parameters Since the results of the MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA are sensitive to the primary parameters, we used the Taguchi setting approach to set parameters to detect the most reliable solution. Also, utilizing the Taguchi approach, the proper factors (primary parameters) were defined and the level of each factor was chosen. Hence, the design of the test was determined and the best combination of factors for the MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA algorithms was defined. In Table 6, the value of the primary parameters used in the MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA algorithms is shown. Then, each test was repeated 10 times per run, and the value of the objective function was recorded for each one of them. According to the number of parameters and their levels, there should be 5^4 trials for MOSEO, 5^2 trials for MOSA, 5^5 trials for MOKA, 5^6 trials for MOPSO, 5^7 trials for MOFFA which is 625, 25, 3125, 15625, and 87125 respectively, which adds up to a very high number. Thus, we have used Table 7 instead of the implementation of 625, 25, 3125, 15625, and 87125 trials for all the algorithms. This table corresponds to the L25 Taguchi test design to reduce the number of trials to 25 for each algorithm. In the Taguchi method, the Signal/Noise (𝑆/𝑁) ratio is applied for analysis, where 𝑆 refers to the response variable and 𝑁 is a standard deviation. The higher the ratio, the more favorable it is. Table 8 contains the corresponding values of S/N, calculated using equation (94), and Figure 17 indicates this ratio for each algorithm.

After calibrating the MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA algorithms, the values of the constraints satisfaction 1  and 2  were set as 0.7 to analyze their results. In addition, the weight coefficient ( =0.5) and penalty coefficients (  = =400) were considered. For more precise computations, each instance was replicated 3 times per run utilizing each algorithm. Tables 9 and10 show the objective function values and computational times per problem utilizing the different algorithms. Figure 18 displays the computational times required by the MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA algorithms. As shown in the tables, the run time of the optimization GAMS software 24.1.3 and MATLAB R2016b is increasing for the small-sized problem instances, while no solutions can be obtained for the largesized ones. This shows the inefficacy of the GAMS solver for large-sized problems. The computational time required by the metaheuristic procedures is minimum for the multi-objective firefly algorithm and maximum for the multi-objective simulated annealing.

div.head: Comparison of proposed multi-objective metaheuristic algorithms
div.p: In this section, we present a comparative analysis of the performance and effectiveness of the proposed multi-objective metaheuristic algorithms according to four evaluation metrics. These metrics are the assessment indicators of the Pareto optimum sets i.e., SNS, NPS, MS, and MID per proposed problem [51]. The outputs were averaged for a set of 25 runs, and the run times are in the same range for each problem size. The outputs are shown in Tables 11121314.

Figure 19 shows an example of the non-dominated solutions for instance LP4. This figure shows that there are several significant similarities between the presented metaheuristic algorithms, particularly between MOKA and MOPSO. According to this figure, MOSEO and MOSA show the worst performance and effectiveness between the proposed metaheuristic algorithms, whereas MOFFA dominates over the other algorithms. Besides, MOFFA achieves an area with the lowest delivery time and total cost and highest reliability of transportation systems. Generally, the rest of the proposed algorithms' solutions are close to each other. Furthermore, to determine the best metaheuristic, we conducted a set of statistical comparisons between algorithms according to the Pareto optimum analyses. We did this by transforming, the outputs presented in Tables 8 Min based on the nature of metrics [52,53]. It is clear that a lower value of RDI indicates a higher quality of the algorithm. As a result, we obtained the means plot and Least Significant Difference (LSD) for the proposed metaheuristic algorithms.

The mixed efficiency analysis by comparison of the metaheuristic algorithms is shown in Figure 20. In Figure 20(a), based on NPS, although MOFFA indicates the most reliable solution's quality, its performance range is rather wide. However, the other graphs show a robust behavior of MOFFA, whereas the quality of MOSEO shows a weak efficiency. Figure 20(b) shows that MOFFA has a better robust behavior compared to other proposed algorithms in the MID metric. According to this figure, MOFFA demonstrates the best efficiency and the most confident outcome. In Figure 20 (c), MOSA has the weakest result in terms of the MS metric, while MOKA demonstrates a robust behavior and MOFFA shows the best efficiency. Finally, the results based on the SNS metric in Figure 20(d) show that MOFFA has the best efficiency and demonstrates better quality. Likewise, the quality of MOPSO is nearby to MOKA. Besides, MOSEO demonstrates a confident form of proposed metaheuristic algorithms, while MOSA is the worst algorithm according to the SNS metric. As an overall result, the above-mentioned metrics indicate that MOFFA guarantees better quality and performance than the other proposed metaheuristic algorithms.

div.head: Sensitivity analysis
div.p: This section contains the results of three tests applied to assess the sensitivity analysis of the impact of the parameters on the values of the decision variables and the objective function of the PSCN model. Since the MOFFA algorithm proved to be the most effective one in the comparisons, we used it for this sensitivity analysis, applied to the large-sized experimental problem LP3. The results of each test include the value of the total cost (𝑇𝐶), the delivery time (𝐷𝑇), and the reliability (𝑅).
The first experiment considers modifications in the parameter of the fixed cost of internal and foreign manufacturing centers

div.head: Discussion and managerial insights
div.p: Generally, a PSCN model aims to optimize the production, distribution, allocation, location, ordering, routing, inventory, and transportation of pharmaceutical products utilizing multi-modal Journal Pre-proof main parameters contained in the present paper are important elements for investigation in practice, notwithstanding the fact that other parameters of equivalent importance could also be determined with further study.

div.head: Conclusions and future studies
div.p: In this paper, we have developed a comprehensive multi-period, multi-echelon, and multi-product MINLP model for a PSCN problem with considering multi-modal transportation under uncertainty. The second innovation contained in this paper is the development of a new robust fuzzy programming technique to investigate the effects and efficiency of uncertainty input parameters related to transportation cost, purchase cost, and capacity of the warehouses, distribution centers, and vehicles. Also, this extensive implementation of uncertainty in the parameters in our model makes it more realistic and closer to the real world. Nevertheless, there exist other different approaches and methods for coping with uncertain parameters in supply chain problems. The determination of how efficient each one of these approaches and methods may be requires a detailed comparison based on real case studies that could be suggested as one possible direction for future research.

With respect to our PSCN problem, exact algorithms are able to find the exact solution, but their solving time increases significantly with the size of the problem. Also, they are directly not applicable to large-size problems: some practical-size problems are so large that their optimal solution cannot be achieved within a reasonable timeframe. For this reason, near-optimal solutions can be found, in a way that their quality is acceptable and can be achieved with relatively low computational cost. Several approaches, including meta-heuristic algorithms, have been proposed to design acceptable solutions, and meta-heuristic algorithms including MOSEO, MOSA, MOKA, MOPSO, and MOFFA are used in this paper. The proposed metaheuristic algorithms were tuned through Taguchi's method and compared with GAMS and CPLEX in the small-scale problems, and their capabilities and performances were tested for large-scale problems. The results indicated that MOFFA was able to find an acceptable solution efficiently for a PSCN problem, and its required CPU time was considerably less than that of other algorithms for large-scale problem samples. To validate the presented model and methodology solutions, we also performed several sensitivity analyses on the main parameters.

Our work represents a step forward in the planning of pharmaceutical supply chains, covering the research gaps left by the most recent references on the subject. For instance, [16] considers only capacities and network flows, within a deterministic framework. [17], on the other hand, covers only stores and customers, and while uncertainty is included in the analysis only a decomposition approach is used to find the solution. Similarly, [22] only provides MILP solutions to a small-scale example taking into account only the pharmacy-hospital echelon. [20] deals with location and inventory issues and incorporates uncertainty with the subsequent sensitivity analyses, but the objective function is limited to cost. In one of the two approaches most similar to ours, [21] takes into account procurement, production and distribution in a multi-objective approach with uncertainty, but the results are limited to the MILP solution for a small example, with no sensitivity analysis provided. The other one [23] compares three metaheuristic algorithms to solve the problem, but the only consideration of uncertainty is the use of trapezoidal fuzzy numbers to express demand.

Besides the proposed meta-heuristic algorithms, other algorithms, such as neural networks, colony optimization, whale optimization, imperial competitive optimization algorithms, etc. could be used for comparison in PSCN optimization. Also, there are many problems such as sustainability, pricing, and regulations, etc. or other uncertainty approaches such as stochastic, probability, possibilistic, etc. that can be incorporated to improve the model and solution methodologies in future studies.

div.head: Multi-objective 𝐤𝐞𝐬𝐡𝐭𝐞𝐥 algorithm
div.p: The 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙 algorithm (KA) for optimization problems was introduced by [45]. In a similar procedure to other meta-heuristic algorithms, the KA begins with an initial population called 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙. 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 descend into the lake to find a good solution. A 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙 that finds the best food for the first time is called Lucky 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙 (LK). The Lucky 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙 searches to find more food, and also for attracting adjoining 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠. In addition, if a better food is found around a Lucky 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙, it and its adjoining 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 are rotated around the new and better source. Also, after eating food in that area, Lucky 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 and their adjoining 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 are identified and moved to a different location. After some time, Lucky 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 will remain in the lake in their hope to find food [45,46]. Some of them go to places where no 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙 has ever been. Also, some others who do not have the hope of finding food fly into other lakes. Inversely, some new 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 will land in the lake.

In the algorithm, the 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙 location corresponds to a solution of the problem. The better food represents less cost in the minimization objective function or the maximum solution in the maximization objective function. The 𝐾𝐴 has two phases, namely intensification and diversification. In the intensification phase, Lucky 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 absorb adjoining 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 and rotate around the food source. In reality, in the intensification phase, the algorithm moves towards the local (or global) optimum. In the diversification phase, some 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠 move inside the lake to find intact places (solutions), and some other Keshtels go to other lakes and are replaced with new 𝐾𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑡𝑒𝑙𝑠.
For more information about the MOKA algorithm, the reader can refer to [46]. The pseudo-code of the KA algorithm is shown in Figure 9.

div.head: Multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm
div.p: The particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm was introduced by [47]. It models and simulates the behavior of birds flying in a group or fish swimming in a school. Each member in this group is defined by its velocity vector and position vector in the search space. In each iteration, the new particle position is defined according to the vector of velocity and position vector in the search space. Also, the new particle position is updated according to the current velocity vector, the best position found by that particle, and the best position ever found by any particle in the group. For more information about the MOPSO algorithm, the reader can refer to [48]. Figure 10 displays the pseudo-code of the MOPSO algorithm.

div.head: Multi-objective firefly algorithm
div.p: The firefly algorithm (FFA) was introduced by [49], and is mainly inspired by the light connection between fireflies. This algorithm can be considered as the swarm intelligence, in which the co-operation (and possibly the competition) of simpler and less intelligent members creates a higher degree of intelligence that is certainly not achievable by any of the components alone. Therefore, this algorithm is J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

div.head: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f
div.p: Journal Pre-proof transportation. In many cases, although, and perhaps specifically in European countries where the management of PSCN is of specific concern, PSCN management is failing to deliver satisfactorily all the required decision support. In this regard, all the logistics factors included in the PSCN need to be carefully analyzed. This includes the following:  Allocations of internal and foreign manufacturing centers to warehouses, DCs, and customers, of the warehouses to the DCs and customers and the DCs to customers in the different routes.  Reliability of the transportation systems.  The existing costs such as tariff, transportation, ordering, purchasing, inventory holding, penalty, packaging, delivery, and stock keeping. The purpose of this paper is to extend an integrated structure for a PSCN optimization that is efficient. Efficiency needs a multi-objective optimization process that accommodates all production, distribution, ordering, allocation, transportation, purchasing, delivery, routing, and reliability decisions across a presented PSCN with intermediate facilities as well as an algorithm to better solve this complex problem that is computationally manageable and robust.

As a result, we have focused on the PSCN optimization with multi-objectives and complex constraints. According to the assumptions of multi-modal transportation, reliability of transportation systems, the delivery time of pharmaceutical products, tariff costs, and uncertainty of input parameters, we have provided a new complex PSCN formulation. This includes a MINLP model to solve small instances of the problem and five multi-objective metaheuristics algorithms. Moreover, due to the natural uncertainty of input parameters, we have developed a new robust-fuzzy procedure. Thus, the paper contains objective functions that accommodate the full domain of uncertainty for the optimization of the PSCN. The performance of the suggested multi-objective algorithms, particularly MOFFA, is promising for the specific problem considered here and also in terms of its successful application to similar supply chain problems.

Whereas the initial aim of our work was to extend an integrated network for a PSCN optimization that is efficient, some insights into the reliability of the PSCN have also emerged. The problem description as a multi-level, multi-product, and multi-period formulation makes the model more realistic. One important insight is that the conceptual alternation from supply chain management to PSCN requires a feasible solution to achieve better designs of pharmaceutical networks within a pharmaceutical supply chain. Our work shows that the incorporation of reliability issues through the use of multi-modal transportation, production, distribution, ordering, delivery, inventory holding, purchasing, transportation, allocation of pharmaceutical products during various period times, analyzing the biological instances in the manufacturing centers to update the pharmaceutical products records, generates the robust potential for added value across all pharmaceutical industries to cover the satisfaction of patients.

Other practical insights are related to the sensitivity analysis of the objective functions with changes in key parameters, as shown in Figures 212223. Specifically, the reduction of the total costs and delivery times of pharmaceutical products as well as the increase of the reliability of the transportation system and routes in the network indicated in Figures 21-23 calls for further attention. Intrinsically, analyzing the different proposed multi-objective algorithms by utilizing the SNS, MS, NPS and MID evaluation metrics of the Pareto frontier emphasize that MOFFA is typically more reliable than the other proposed metaheuristics, as shown in Figure 20.

Eventually, the fact that such pragmatic insights are possible when a more reliable PSCN is investigated forcefully encourages the further development and application of high-proficiency algorithms, such as MOFFA. The potential utility of an integrated structure of PSCN for transportation, production, distribution, ordering, delivery, inventory holding, purchasing, transportation, and allocation of the pharmaceutical products for more efficient decision-making is demonstrably high. The  Integrating production, distribution, purchasing, inventory holding, ordering, allocation, and routing decisions in the PSCN problem for the first time according to the papers analyzed in the literature review,  Considering three objective functions focusing on total cost, time as the significant objective because of the significance to deliver some pharmaceutical amount of products within the shortest timeframe, and reliability of transportation systems and routes in the PSCN,  Considering uncertainty for the parameters related to order, transportation, purchase, and delivery costs and capacity of the warehouse, the distribution centers, and the vehicles,  Developing a novel robust fuzzy approach to manage uncertainty in PSCN parameters,  Proposing multi-objective metaheuristic algorithms to reach fast high-quality solutions,  Providing several sensitivity analyses on the main parameters.
